topic.name: Ancient Near East & Egypt (Biblical Core)
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Ancient Near East & Egypt (Biblical Core) in History & Social Studies

objectives.objective_text: Identify Assyria as a scary army.
Name Nebuchadnezzar as a king of Babylon.
Identify Nineveh as the capital of Assyria.
Identify Babylon as a big, beautiful city.
Name Hammurabi as a king who made rules.
Identify Babylon's location on a map.
Identify Persia as a huge kingdom.
Name King Cyrus who let God's people go home.
Identify the Royal Road.
Identify Mesopotamia as the 'Land Between Rivers'.
Name the wheel and writing as things they invented.
Identify the 'Cradle of Civilization'.
Recall that they took God's people away from their homes.
Observe the Ishtar Gate (blue bricks).
Recall that rules help people live together safely.
Observe a stone with writing on it (stele).
Recall that they used horses to send mail.
Observe that God uses kings to help His people.
Recall that Abraham came from a city here called Ur.
Observe pictures of Ziggurats (temple towers).
Summarize the fall of Israel (to Assyria) and Judah (to Babylon).
Explain why these empires were called 'fierce'.
Explain the policy of deportation and exile.
Defend the fulfillment of prophecies concerning Nineveh and Babylon.
Identify the Pyramids and the Sphinx.
Name the Pharaoh as the king of Egypt.
Identify Hieroglyphs as picture writing.
Summarize the Code of Hammurabi ('Eye for an eye').
Explain why writing down laws is important.
Explain the role of the king as the guardian of justice.
Defend the superiority of biblical law regarding the value of life.
Summarize the story of Esther (Queen of Persia).
Explain how the Persians treated people nicely (tolerance).
Explain Zoroastrianism (religion of Persia).
Defend the biblical prophecy regarding Cyrus (Isaiah 45).
Summarize the geography of the Tigris and Euphrates valleys.
Explain what a City-State is (like Ur or Babylon).
Explain the significance of the 'Standard of Ur'.
Defend the biblical account of the origin of nations in this region.
Compare the Assyrian war machine with Babylonian culture.
Analyze the military tactics of the Assyrians (siege warfare).
Interpret the Hanging Gardens of Babylon (wonder of the world).
Connect the prophets (Isaiah, Jeremiah) to these political powers.
Recall that the Nile River was very important.
Observe mummies and painted coffins.
Compare Hammurabi's laws with God's laws (Ten Commandments).
Analyze the class distinctions in Hammurabi's Code.
Interpret the concept of 'Lex Talionis' (Law of Retaliation).
Connect Babylon to the later exile of Judah.
Compare the Persian rule with the Assyrian rule.
Analyze the administrative genius of Darius (Satraps).
Interpret the Cyrus Cylinder as historical evidence.
Connect the Persian Empire to the events of Ezra and Nehemiah.
Compare the life of a farmer in Sumer with a nomad.
Analyze the political structure of the first empires (Akkad/Sargon).
Interpret the religious worldview of polytheism in the ANE.
Connect the invention of Cuneiform to the preservation of history.
Evaluate the role of these empires as 'the rod of God's anger'.
Summarize how the Nile flooding helped grow food.
Explain why they built Pyramids (tombs for the afterlife).
Explain the significance of the Rosetta Stone.
Defend the historicity of the Hebrew sojourn in Egypt.
Evaluate the justice system of Ancient Babylon.
Evaluate the strategy of religious toleration for empire stability.
Evaluate the 'hydraulic hypothesis' (irrigation leads to government).
Construct a geopolitical map of the 8th-6th century BC.
Synthesize the cultural preservation achieved by the Library of Ashurbanipal.
Compare the Old, Middle, and New Kingdoms.
Analyze the social hierarchy of Egypt (Pharaoh as god-king).
Interpret the Book of the Dead and beliefs about the soul.
Connect Egyptian stability to its geography (desert protection).
Construct a comparative legal analysis of Mosaic Law vs. Hammurabi's Code.
Synthesize the rise of Babylon as a theological symbol in Scripture.
Construct a profile of the Achaemenid Empire's extent.
Synthesize the conflict between Persia and Greece (Marathon/Thermopylae).
Construct a timeline of the rise and fall of Sumerian and Akkadian power.
Synthesize the cultural legacy of Mesopotamia on later empires.
Construct a profile of a specific Pharaoh (e.g., Hatshepsut or Ramses II).
Synthesize the relationship between Egyptian religion and political power.
Evaluate the architectural engineering of the Giza plateau.
